name: Wikipedia Classic
author: Wikimedia Contributors
description: The iconic introductory puzzle from the Wikipedia Sudoku article. Solvable with naked singles throughout—a perfect first puzzle.

name: Morning Glow
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 05 from Project Euler Problem 96. A bright, generous puzzle with 36 clues—great for a warm-up.

name: Weekend Edition
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 08 from Project Euler Problem 96. Lavishly filled with 36 given digits—a puzzle for a relaxed solve.

name: Clear Path
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 16 from Project Euler Problem 96. Plenty of clues in every box—an easy and satisfying fill.

name: Open Road
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 17 from Project Euler Problem 96. Well-distributed givens open up every region quickly.

name: Gentle Wave
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 33 from Project Euler Problem 96. Chains of naked singles cascade through the grid in a satisfying wave.

name: Easy Flow
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 40 from Project Euler Problem 96. An asymmetric layout with a generous middle section that flows easily.

name: Classic Open
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 01 from Project Euler Problem 96. A well-balanced puzzle requiring pointing pairs and naked pairs.

name: Double Step
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 02 from Project Euler Problem 96. A classic medium—naked and hidden pairs bring this one home.

name: Triple Box
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 03 from Project Euler Problem 96. Requires pointing pairs and hidden singles to advance past the early stages.

name: Steady Pace
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 04 from Project Euler Problem 96. A medium puzzle with a steady, even solving rhythm.

name: Crossword
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 10 from Project Euler Problem 96. A satisfying medium with a crossword-like clue structure.

name: Diagonal Rise
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 11 from Project Euler Problem 96. Clues arranged along a diagonal axis—hidden pair analysis needed.

name: Blue Skies
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 12 from Project Euler Problem 96. A bright, symmetric puzzle that opens up nicely with standard techniques.

name: Winding Path
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 18 from Project Euler Problem 96. A pleasant medium challenge that rewards a methodical approach.

name: Warm Breeze
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 19 from Project Euler Problem 96. Dense clue distribution with a few naked triples required.

name: Mirror Dance
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 21 from Project Euler Problem 96. A near-symmetric layout solved by hidden singles and naked pairs.

name: Box Garden
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 23 from Project Euler Problem 96. Dense corner boxes with strategic pointing pairs in the middle.

name: Golden Gate
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 25 from Project Euler Problem 96. Strong corner and edge clues bracket a sparse interior.

name: Four Corners
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 34 from Project Euler Problem 96. Corner boxes richly filled—use them to crack open the centre.

name: Hidden Keys
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 35 from Project Euler Problem 96. Several hidden singles are the key to unlocking the grid.

name: Symmetry
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 36 from Project Euler Problem 96. A satisfying near-symmetric layout solved by naked pairs and pointing pairs.

name: Cross Roads
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 37 from Project Euler Problem 96. Two strong bands of clues intersect at the centre.

name: Spiral
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 38 from Project Euler Problem 96. A spiralling clue distribution that rewards methodical scanning.

name: Inner Circle
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 39 from Project Euler Problem 96. A near-symmetric puzzle with a strong inner ring of clues.

name: Sparse Crown
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 06 from Project Euler Problem 96. Only 24 givens with an empty centre row—requires hidden pairs and column analysis.

name: Stone Wall
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 07 from Project Euler Problem 96. A sparse grid requiring box-line reduction and pointing pairs to break through.

name: Cold North
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 09 from Project Euler Problem 96. Sparse givens concentrated in the lower half—work backwards from what you know.

name: Iron Cliffs
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 14 from Project Euler Problem 96. Empty central rows and sparse columns demand pointing pairs and hidden singles.

name: Glacier
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 15 from Project Euler Problem 96. A cool, sparse puzzle requiring patience and systematic candidate elimination.

name: Empty Horizon
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 20 from Project Euler Problem 96. Three entirely empty rows force deep interplay between columns and boxes.

name: Fog Bank
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 22 from Project Euler Problem 96. Hidden singles and naked pairs buried in a sparse, foggy grid.

name: Deep Water
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 24 from Project Euler Problem 96. Sparse top and bottom sections require advanced candidate narrowing.

name: Shadow
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 26 from Project Euler Problem 96. Only 24 givens leave many blank regions that must be deduced carefully.

name: Eclipse
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 27 from Project Euler Problem 96. Strong diagonal bands flank an almost-empty centre.

name: Twin Voids
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 28 from Project Euler Problem 96. Two empty rows at top and bottom bracket a richly-clued centre—use them wisely.

name: Ridgeline
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 29 from Project Euler Problem 96. Clues cluster along the edges—work inward with pointing pairs.

name: Granite
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 30 from Project Euler Problem 96. A hard and unyielding layout requiring multiple passes of elimination.

name: Sandstone
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 31 from Project Euler Problem 96. Clues concentrate on the diagonals, leaving key regions sparse.

name: Obsidian
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 32 from Project Euler Problem 96. Only 26 givens with an empty centre row—solid technique required throughout.

name: Steel Curtain
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 42 from Project Euler Problem 96. Top rows heavily sparse—punch through with column analysis.

name: Silent Storm
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 43 from Project Euler Problem 96. An empty centre row creates a storm beneath the surface of this deceptively tricky grid.

name: Dark Sky
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 44 from Project Euler Problem 96. Only 24 givens scattered across the grid—multi-step elimination required.

name: Midnight
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 45 from Project Euler Problem 96. A well-structured but challenging puzzle requiring hidden pairs and pointing pairs.

name: Black Ice
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 46 from Project Euler Problem 96. Slippery sparse regions require careful candidate tracking.

name: Storm Front
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 48 from Project Euler Problem 96. A complex grid where the solution breaks open unexpectedly.

name: Iron Gate
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 50 from Project Euler Problem 96. The final grid—25 givens with locked candidates needed to push through.

name: Mountain Peak
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 13 from Project Euler Problem 96—notorious as the hardest puzzle in the set. Requires advanced techniques including X-Wings and locked candidates.

name: The Abyss
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 47 from Project Euler Problem 96. Only 23 givens—a near-minimum puzzle where every clue is precious.

name: Bedrock
author: Project Euler
description: Grid 49 from Project Euler Problem 96. A minimal 22-clue puzzle requiring chains and advanced logical deductions.

name: AI Escargot
author: Arto Inkala
description: Created in 2006 by Finnish mathematician Arto Inkala, who claimed it was the world's hardest Sudoku. Requires tracking up to 8 simultaneous logical relationships. Rated among the highest difficulty puzzles ever published.

name: Hardest Sudoku
author: Arto Inkala
description: Created by Arto Inkala in 2010 for The Daily Mail. Rated 11 on a standard 5-star scale—requires 10-step lookaheads. The definitive extreme Sudoku challenge.
